indicators.justification:
Tajikistan's Third National Communication (TNC) to the UNFCCC, submitted in 2014, includes a GHG inventory for the years 1990(1), therefore it can be assumed that the data is being collected but, it is not available online. Additionally, emission data appears to be available through some non-governmental organizations, however, it is accessible only based on agreement.

Sources:

1.https://www.climatelinks.org/sites/default/files/asset/document/2019_USAID_Tajikistan%20Factsheet.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
Nationally published data includes detailed information on greenhouse gas emissions and targets reported to the UNFCCC.
Data contains detailed information on sources of greenhouse gas emissions.
Emissions data includes, or site where emissions data is made available links to, details of land use effects on emissions.
The dataset contains unique identifiers for greenhouse gas emissions that allow easy assessment across inventories, reduction commitments, and sources.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
According to the CBD First National Report(1) The Red Data Book of Tajikistan includes 226 plant and 162 animal species, which are rare or endangered. The report mentions the following categories of plants and animals, listed in the Red Data Book of Tajikistan: Fungi, Bryophytes, Filices, Gymnosperms, Angiosperms, Fish, Reptiles, Birds, Mammals, Mantis, Proboscidea, Bugs, Coleopterous or beetles, Lepidopterous, Hymenopterous, Mollusks. There is no evidence of the red book being available online, much less in the form of a machine readable dataset.

Sources:

1. https://www.cbd.int/doc/world/tj/tj-nr-01-p04-en.pdf

indicators.justification:
Having taken part in the beneficial ownership pilot in 2014 Tajikistan published its beneficial ownership report in English and in Russian. Prior to producing the beneficial ownership report, Tajikistan also undertook scoping work(1) documenting existing definitions and laws on beneficial ownership applicable to Tajikistan, as well as the information kept in company registers and license registers. In September 2015 Tajikistan's EITI Council produced an evaluation report(2) on the beneficial ownership pilot, documenting the completeness of the disclosed information, data collection method, challenges and recommendations for further work on beneficial ownership.

Sources:

1.https://eiti.org/document/kyrgyzstan-scoping-note-for-beneficial-ownership-pilot-project
2.https://eiti.org/files/documents/en-kyrgyzstan-bo-evaluation-report.pdf

indicators.justification:
According to the Open Company Data Index, there used to be a web portal where company data was freely accessible(1), however, this website is not accessible as of today(2). Some data can be retrieved on the website of the tax committee(3), but it only includes the names, IDs, and status of the companies, and seems to only be available for companies registered after 2020. Furthermore, the data can be requested via an FoI request, as stipulated in the LAW OF THE REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN ON STATE REGISTRATION OF LEGAL ENTITIES AND INDIVIDUAL ENTREPRENEURS(4).

Sources:

1.http://registries.opencorporates.com/jurisdiction/tj
2.https://andoz.tj/index.php/ru/elektronnye-uslugi
3.https://andoz.tj/Fehrist/Ur?culture=ru-RU
4.http://ncz.tj/content/%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD-%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%83%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD-%D0%BE-%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9-%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8-%D1%8E%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D1%85-%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%86%C2%A0-%D0%B8-%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D1%85

indicators.justification:
The data is labeled as available until 2019 on the new website of the National Statistics Office(1), although the download function does not seem to be working. I had to switch to the old version(2) of the website to download the excel file, however in this case only data up to 2016 is available. Most of the assessed datasets lack disaggregation and are missing important categories, such as disaggregation by month, cause of death, age, etc.

1.https://www.stat.tj/en/database-socio-demographic-sector
2.http://oldstat.ww.tj/en/database/socio-demographic-sector/

indicators.justification:
There is no accessible data online containing land tenure, cadastre, or land use information from Tajikistan. 
Some government websites, particularly that of the State Committee on Land Management and Geodesy (SCLMG), are unavailable to be viewed, so it is not possible at this time to verify if the data exists on these websites (1)
While a Single Window, Cadastre, and Urban Monitoring  Implementation Center has been established in Tajikistan (2), some of the functions of which contain managing land use data, none of it is available as open data as of yet. 

Sources: 
1) http://zamin.tj/index.php/ru/

2) https://tajsohtmon.tj/ru/komitet/org_struktura/1729-gosudarstvennoe-uchrezhdenie-centr-realizacii-edinogo-okna-kadastra-i-gradostroitelnogo-monitoringa.html

The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.

indicators.justification:
The main legal act regulating the area of public procurement in Tajikistan is the Law of 2006 on Public Procurement of Goods, Works and Services (1). 
Some registers of public procurement exist on the website of the Agency for Goods, Works and Services of the Government of Tajikistan (2) and the newer procurement website(3). However, these datasets are often incomplete, and large gaps exist in the system. Its publication as open data is even more limited. Tajikistan was evaluated as one of the most poorly performing countries in terms of transparent public procurement by TPPR in 2020(4).

Sources: 
1) Law of 2006 on Public Procurement of Goods, Works and Services

indicators.justification:
Having taken part in the beneficial ownership pilot in 2014 Tajikistan published its beneficial ownership report in English and in Russian. Prior to producing the beneficial ownership report, Tajikistan also undertook scoping work documenting existing definitions and laws on beneficial ownership applicable to Tajikistan, as well as the information kept in company registers and license registers(1).

Members of the EITI Council and the national secretariat published Tajikistan's beneficial ownership roadmap(2) identifying actions needed for further beneficial ownership disclosures. In April 2019, the EITI Council has updated the BO Roadmap. Also, the EITI National Secretariat with support from EBRD has conducted the MSG capacity building workshop on beneficial ownership in November 2018.

Sources:

1.https://eiti.org/tajikistan
2.https://eiti.org/document/tajikistan-eiti-beneficial-ownership-roadmap

indicators.justification:
The Law No. 1537, adopted on 3 August 2018, On Personal Data Protection is the main regulatory framework in place governing the gathering and protection of personal data (1). The law lays out the guidelines for gathering, storing, and managing personal data across the country of Tajikistan. 
The Law is explicit regarding the need of the subjects of the data to provide consent regarding its gathering. Article 22 (along with several provisions in the other articles) guarantees the subjects the rights to access the information, request corrections in case of incorrect or misleading information, although no formalized methods for such requests are provided in the Law. Article 25 lays out the responsibilities of the data holders, while Article 26 indicates that violations of these guidelines will result in the data holders being held responsible in accordance with the rest of Tajikistan's legislation. The Law itself does not outline the punitive measures in its text. 

Sources: 
1) The Law No. 1537, adopted on 3 August 2018, On Personal Data Protection
http://ncz.tj/content/%D0%BE-%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%89%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D1%85-%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D1%85

According to Article 2 of the Constitution of the Republic of Tajikistan (1), Tajik is the state language of Tajikistan, with Russian as the language of international communication. indicators.justification:
The LAW ON PUBLIC FINANCE OF THE REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN (1) stipulates that after the approval of the state fiscal and tax policy for the period of budget planning, the budget document is published annually. The Government discloses the broad parameters of fiscal policies in advance of the Executive's Budget Proposal; outlines the government's economic forecast, anticipated revenue, expenditures, and debt.

indicators.justification:
The requirement of public officials to fill out declarations of their assets is laid out in multiple Tajik laws. The Law of Republic of Tajikistan "On Counteracting Corruption" (1) is one such law. 
Other laws lay out additional provisions relating to declarations. For example, a recently adopted addendum to the Law on State Service (2) states that special verification processes will be employed against public officials if it is revealed that the information they provided in their declarations was false. 
Nevertheless, the gathering of the data is systematized, and nowhere is it made clear that this information should be publicly available. The mechanisms of control and verification are similarly unclear (3). 

Sources: 
1) https://andoz.tj/docs/zakoni/%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%20%D0%A0%D0%A2%20%D0%9E%20%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%B9%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5%20%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%80%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8.pdf

2) https://andoz.tj/docs/zakoni/l_%E2%84%962_government-service-RT_ru.pdf

3) https://cabar.asia/ru/deklaratsii-tadzhikskih-chinovnikov-kto-ih-dolzhen-proveryat

indicators.justification:
Constitutional Law of the Republic of Tajikistan "On Elections to the Majlisi Oli" (1) is the primary framework for governing the electoral activities of the political parties and individuals in Tajikistan. 
According to Article 9 of Law, the funds used to conduct electoral campaigns are transferred to and disbursed by the national bank of Tajikistan "Amonatbonk", which is responsible for informing the election commission of all financial aid and expenses from a candidate's account. This information is provided to the commission upon request. 
The Law has no mention of the publication of the gathered data as open data, nor of any responsibility to inform the public regarding the financial matters of the campaigns in other ways. 

Sources: 
1) Constitutional Law of the Republic of Tajikistan "On Elections to the Majlisi Oli" 
http://kmir.tj/ru/2019/12/07/konstitutsionnyj-zakon-respubliki-tadzhikistan-o-vyborah-madzhlisi-oli-respubliki-tadzhikistan/

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of this use.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.indicator_name: Capability (C): Political freedoms and civil liberties
Capability (C): Business use of digital tools
Capability (C): Use of standards and methods in statistic offices
Use (U): Data use by international organizations
